official-title.#text:
To establish within the Department of Education the
		  Innovation Inspiration school grant program, and for other
		  purposes.

committee-name.#text:
Committee on Education and the
			 Workforce

cosponsor.#tail:
) introduced
			 the following bill; which was referred to the

short-title.#text:
Innovation Inspiration School Grant
			 Program Act

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

According to the
			 National Science Board’s 2010 Science and Engineering Indicators, only 5
			 percent of American college graduates major in engineering. In Asia, about 20
			 percent of all baccalaureate degrees are in engineering and in China about 33
			 percent of baccalaureate degrees are in engineering.

Although 4th
			 graders in the United States score well against international competition,
			 students in the United States fall near the bottom or dead last by 12th grade
			 in mathematics and science, respectively.

Admissions
			 requirements for undergraduate engineering schools include a solid background
			 in mathematics (algebra, geometry, trigonometry, and calculus) and science
			 (biology, chemistry, and physics), in addition to courses in English, social
			 studies, and humanities.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, overall engineering employment is expected to grow
			 by 11 percent from 2008 through 2018, and, as a group, engineers earn some of
			 the highest average starting salaries among individuals holding baccalaureate
			 degrees.

text.#text: According to the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, engineers should be creative, inquisitive, analytical, and
			 detail-oriented. Engineers should be able to work as part of a team and to
			 communicate well, both orally and in writing. Communication abilities are
			 becoming increasingly important as engineers interact more frequently with
			 specialists in a wide range of fields outside engineering.

text.#text: According to the

Exposure to
			 project- and problem-based learning, in a competitive team environment, gives
			 9th through 12th graders the skills that they need to be successful in
			 engineering programs of study and engineering careers.

According to
			 Brandeis University’s Center for Youth and Communities, participants in FIRST
			 Robotics (a nonprofit organization that inspires young people to be science and
			 technology leaders by engaging the young people in mentor-based
			 programs)—

are nearly 2 times
			 as likely to major in a science or engineering field; and

are more than 3
			 times as likely to have majored specifically in engineering.
In this Act:

term.#tail:
means science, technology, engineering (including
			 robotics), or mathematics.

text.#text:
The
			 term

term.#tail:
means a STEM education method or
			 strategy such as incorporating self-directed student learning, inquiry-based
			 learning, cooperative learning in small groups, collaboration with mentors in
			 the field of study, and participation in STEM-related competitions.

text.#text: The term

The goals of the Innovation Inspiration grant program
			 are—

to support the
			 participation of students in nonprofit STEM competitions;

to foster
			 innovation and broaden interest in, and access to, careers in the STEM fields
			 by investing in programs supported by educators and professional mentors who
			 receive hands-on training and ongoing communications that strengthen the
			 interactions of the educators and mentors with—

students who are
			 involved in STEM activities; and

other students in
			 the STEM classrooms and communities of such educators and mentors; and

to encourage
			 collaboration among students, engineers, and professional mentors.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
is authorized to award grants, on a
			 competitive basis, to local educational agencies to enable the local
			 educational agencies—

text.#text: The

to promote STEM in
			 secondary schools;

to support the
			 participation of secondary school students in non-traditional STEM teaching
			 methods; and

to broaden
			 secondary school students' access to careers in STEM.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall award each grant under this Act for a period of not more than 5
			 years.

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall award a grant under this Act in an amount that is sufficient to
			 carry out the goals of this Act.

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
at such time, in such manner,
			 and containing such information as the

text.#text:
Each local educational agency desiring a grant under this
			 Act shall submit an application to the

The
			 application shall, at a minimum, include a description of how the local
			 educational agency will—

carry out STEM
			 teaching programs that will use a non-traditional STEM teaching method;

identify and
			 recruit partners and mentors—

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Innovation Inspiration School Grant Program Act/s:4/ss:c/p:1/sp:A

text.#text:
to
			 help carry out the programs described in

plan for
			 sustaining such programs financially beyond the grant period; and

evaluate the grant
			 project and the results of the grant project among participating students,
			 including—

comparing students
			 who participate in the grant project to similar students who do not
			 participate; and
evaluating—

secondary school
			 graduation rates;

rates of
			 attendance at institutions of higher education;

the number of
			 students taking advanced STEM related secondary school classes; and

the ability of
			 students participating in the grant project to partner with professional
			 mentors.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall give priority to
			 applications from local educational agencies that propose to carry out
			 activities that target—

text.#text:
In
			 awarding grants under this section, the

a rural or urban
			 school;

a low-performing
			 school or local educational agency; or

a local
			 educational agency or school that serves low-income students.

Each local educational agency that receives a grant under
			 this Act shall use the grant funds for any of the following:

Promotion of STEM education and career
			 activities.

The purchase of parts and supplies needed to support
			 participation in non-traditional STEM teaching methods.

Incentives and stipends for teachers
			 involved in non-traditional STEM teaching methods outside of their regular
			 teaching duties.

Support and expenses for student and team participation
			 in regional and national nonprofit STEM competitions.

Additional materials and support, such as
			 equipment, facility use, technology, broadband access, and other expenses,
			 directly associated with non-traditional STEM teaching and mentoring.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Innovation Inspiration School Grant Program Act/s:4/ss:c/p:2/sp:G

text.#text:
Carrying
			 out the evaluation described in

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Innovation Inspiration School Grant Program Act/s:4/ss:a

text.#text:
Carrying out other activities that are related to the
			 goals of the grant program, as described in

A
			 local educational agency shall not use grant funds awarded under this Act to
			 participate in any STEM competition that is not a nonprofit competition.

Each local educational agency that receives a grant under
			 this Act may use not more than 2 percent of the grant funds for costs related
			 to the administration of the grant project.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, each local educational agency
			 that receives a grant under this Act shall secure, toward the cost of the
			 activities assisted under the grant, from non-Federal sources, an amount equal
			 to 50 percent of the grant. The non-Federal contribution may be provided in
			 cash or in kind.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Innovation Inspiration School Grant Program Act/s:4/ss:e/p:2

text.#text: The

Grant funds provided to a local educational agency under
			 this Act shall be used to supplement, and not supplant, funds that would
			 otherwise be used for activities authorized under this Act.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall establish an evaluation program to determine the efficacy of
			 the grant program established by this Act, which shall include comparing
			 students participating in a grant project funded under this Act to similar
			 students who do not so participate, in order to assess the impact of student
			 participation on—
